summary: Trained on data until October 2023, the AI4K Group at IBM Research Ruschlikon includes various researchers.
Docling is an MIT-licensed open-source package for PDF conversion, utilizing AI models DocLayNet and TableFormer for layout and table recognition.
Docling is an open-source tool for efficient PDF conversion to JSON/Markdown, utilizing advanced AI models for layout analysis.
Docling converts PDFs to JSON or Markdown, offering customizable features and batch processing. Installation via PyPI is required.
Docling processes documents with a linear pipeline: parsing, AI feature extraction, and post-processing for metadata and serialization.
Docling's PDF backend processes text and visuals, using custom-built parser and alternatives like pypdfium due to library limitations.
Docling releases two AI models: a layout analysis model and TableFormer, with pre-trained weights and inference code available.
The layout analysis model detects document elements using RT-DETR architecture, trained on DocLayNet, with ONNX runtime for inference.
TableFormer, a vision-transformer model, predicts table structures from images, handling complexities like cell spans and empty cells.
Docling offers optional OCR support using EasyOCR, but it's slow on CPU; seeking collaboration for enhancements.
Docling assembles prediction results into a document datatype, enhancing features, and outputs JSON or Markdown formats.
Docling allows customizable model pipelines for document processing, requiring implementations to follow the Python Callable interface.
Docling's processing speed, resource budget, and backend performance tested on two systems with varying thread configurations.
Docling enables high-quality document conversion for enterprise search, knowledge extraction, and RAG applications, supporting LLM frameworks and dataset construction.
Docling will expand its model library with new classifiers and improve GPU acceleration and PDF backend, inviting contributions.
Data trained until October 2023 includes advancements in OCR, PyTorch, document conversion, and table structure recognition technologies.
This section showcases examples of Docling's output formatted in Markdown and JSON.

topic_name: DocLayNet: A Large Human-Annotated Dataset for Document-Layout Analysis
summary: IBM Research Rueschlikon team members: Birgit Pfitzmann, Christoph Auer, Michele Dolfi, Ahmed S. Nassar, Peter Staar.
DocLayNet is a diverse document-layout dataset improving layout detection accuracy, outperforming PubLayNet and DocBank in general-purpose analysis.
Key areas: Document structure, document analysis, machine learning, computer vision, object detection; copyright permissions for reproduction outlined.

topic_name: DocLayNet: A Large Human-Annotated Dataset for Document-Layout Analysis
summary: IBM Research Rueschlikon team members: Birgit Pfitzmann, Christoph Auer, Michele Dolfi, Ahmed S. Nassar, Peter Staar.
DocLayNet is a diverse document-layout dataset improving layout detection accuracy in PDF conversion, outperforming existing datasets like PubLayNet and DocBank.
Key concepts include document structure, document analysis, machine learning, computer vision, and object detection in KDD '22.
Trained on data until October 2023, focusing on PDF conversion, layout segmentation, object detection, and machine learning datasets.
DocLayNet is a large human-annotated dataset for document layout analysis presented at KDD '22.
Trained on data until October 2023, focusing on PDF conversion, layout segmentation, object detection, and machine learning datasets.
DocLayNet provides a large annotated dataset for document layout analysis, highlighting challenges in machine learning for diverse PDF formats.
DocLayNet aims for high-quality ML models for document-layout analysis, utilizing object detection models like Mask R-CNN and mAP evaluation.
Baseline experiments on Mask R-CNN, Faster R-CNN, and YOLOv5 show low mAP variation, indicating DocLayNet's challenge for ML approaches.
The goal is to enhance high-quality models for document classification using CNNs and COCO format data.
DocLayNet dataset includes various document classes, annotated with inter-annotator agreement measured by mAP@0.5-0.95 metrics.
